title: How to Draw Animals (Kids)

steps.headline: Draw a caterpillar with a couple of rounded "M"s and a circle for the head.
steps.description: Give your caterpillar a nice bright smile while you're at it, and maybe a leaf or two to munch.

steps.headline: Draw a butterfly using more simple shapes and patterns.
steps.description: Include lots of color and try to make the wings as symmetrical as possible.

steps.headline: Draw a frog poised to hop.
steps.description: The point of view can be from the front or the side, so long as you get the angle of the back legs right.

steps.headline: Draw a hamster with little paws and whiskers.
steps.description: Color it a darker brown on the outline and a lighter brown on its stomach, like so.

steps.headline: Draw a rabbit to keep your hamster company.
steps.description: Your picture could be of a domestic rabbit, shown above, or a rabbit like Bugs or the Easter Bunny. It's up to you!

steps.headline: Draw a turtle.
steps.description: You can try your hand at a cartoon turtle, a realistic turtle, or even a snapping turtle—draw them all if you want!

steps.headline: Draw a monkey.
steps.description: This one is a little complicated, but you should end up sketching a cute baby monkey with big eyes and a long tail.

steps.headline: Draw a cow grazing in a field.
steps.description: The more realistic your cow is, the more of a challenge it will be to draw it, but you shouldn't have much trouble so long as your proportions are correct.

steps.headline: Draw a fish as either gray and scaly or as a cartoon.
steps.description: If you'd prefer a fish you could keep in your home, try drawing a goldfish instead.

steps.headline: Draw a dolphin jumping out of the water.
steps.description: Make sure to shade it darker on the bottom!

text: Draw a caterpillar with a couple of rounded "M"s and a circle for the head. Give your caterpillar a nice bright smile while you're at it, and maybe a leaf or two to munch. Draw a butterfly using more simple shapes and patterns. Include lots of color and try to make the wings as symmetrical as possible. Draw a frog poised to hop. The point of view can be from the front or the side, so long as you get the angle of the back legs right. Draw a hamster with little paws and whiskers. Color it a darker brown on the outline and a lighter brown on its stomach, like so. Draw a rabbit to keep your hamster company. Your picture could be of a domestic rabbit, shown above, or a rabbit like Bugs or the Easter Bunny. It's up to you! Draw a turtle. You can try your hand at a cartoon turtle, a realistic turtle, or even a snapping turtle—draw them all if you want! Draw a monkey. This one is a little complicated, but you should end up sketching a cute baby monkey with big eyes and a long tail. Draw a cow grazing in a field. The more realistic your cow is, the more of a challenge it will be to draw it, but you shouldn't have much trouble so long as your proportions are correct. Draw a fish as either gray and scaly or as a cartoon. If you'd prefer a fish you could keep in your home, try drawing a goldfish instead. Draw a dolphin jumping out of the water. Make sure to shade it darker on the bottom!
